title: NHS Transformation Unit Data Sources
text:
What does this website contain?
This website contains information about data sources that are typically used across our projects. The purpose of the website is to provide you with an overview of available data, where to find it and how it can be used.


How can it be used?
This website will be continually developed to add new data sources that are useful to be aware of for our projects. Use the navigation bar on the left hand side of the page to select a data source domain. The individual pages will provide information on:

The background to the data source. How is it curated? Who publishes it? How often?
Where the data can be accessed including links for publicly available datasets.
The types of questions that the data can help to answer and any limitations on its use.



Are we missing a data source?
If you think that there is a useful source of data that we are missing then please let us know so that we can add this. You can either:

Speak to one of the analysts and we can chat about what to include.
If you are feeling brave, create yourself a GitHub account and add an issue to the repository.

title: Activity Datasets
text:
What topics are we interested in?
Analysing activity within different care settings is important to many of the projects that we work on. Routinely collected activity datasets enable detailed analysis and modelling on topics such as:

Who is attending Emergency Departments and Urgent Care Centres? What conditions are they presenting with and how have these presentations changed over time?
Who is admitted to a hospital bed? What proportion of this activity is non-elective? What conditions are people admitted with and what treatment do they receive whilst an inpatient?
How many patients are being seen in outpatient clinics? What treatment are these patients receiving as part of the consultation? How many donâ€™t attend and what happens to them after the appointment?
How many patients are referred to Mental Health services? Which teams are these patients referred to and are they seen within an outpatient or inpatient setting?

title: Emergency Care Dataset (ECDS)
text:
Publisher
NHS Digital (now part of NHS England) receives the ECDS submissions from providers delivering urgent and emergency care to NHS patients. The raw data used for analysis is not publicly available, however, NHS Digital publishes some analyses of ECDS. Their _Hospital Accident & Emergency Activity, 2023-24 provides an overview of activity reported from ECDS.

title: Emergency Care Dataset (ECDS)
text:
Accessing the Data
ECDS data is stored and accessible within several repositories across the NHS for use by approved analysts. One of the analysts will be available to discuss any potential ECDS analysis.

title: Emergency Care Dataset (ECDS)
text:
Frequency of Publishing
Some of the data tables contain flows of daily ECDS updates, typically 48-72 hours in arrears. However, these are subject to change so there are still also monthly ECDS submission data tables.

title: Admitted Patient Care Dataset
text:
Spells and Episodes

A Hospital Provider Spell is the total continuous stay of a PATIENT using a Hospital Bed on premises controlled by a Health Care Provider during which medical care is the responsibility of one or more CONSULTANTS, or the PATIENT is receiving care under one or more Nursing Episodes or Midwife Episodes in a WARD. NHS Data Dictionary
A Consultant Episode (Hospital Provider) is the time a PATIENT spends in the continuous care of one CONSULTANT using Hospital Site or Care Home bed(s) of one Health Care Provider or, in the case of shared care, in the care of two or more CONSULTANTS. NHS Data Dictionary

Therefore, a spell covers the period of care between the patient being admitted and discharged and consists of one or more episodes depending on the care they receive during that spell. The figure below shows three example hospital spells:

 
In the first example a patient has been admitted on 12/11/2023 until they are discharged on 17/11/2023. During the admission they are under the care of a single consultant within General Surgery. Therefore, the entire spell was constructed from a single episode. Each episode of care will also have a diagnoses codes recorded against them. The primary diagnosis code in this case was K740 - Hepatic Fibrosis.
In the second example, the patient was admitted on 12/11/2023 initially under the care of a consultant in General Surgery. They were diagnosed with unspecified liver disease (K769). The next day the patient was transferred to a consultant in Hepatobiliary & Pancreatic Surgery. There diagnosis was updated to K740 - Hepatic Fibrosis and they remained under the care of this consultant until their discharge on 16/11/2023.
In the final example, the patient is transferred a day after admission to Hepatobiliary & Pancreatic Surgery. Here they are diagnosed with Hepatic Fibrosis. Subsequently, they have a third episode of care under a Respiratory consultant where they are primarily treated for influenza.

title: Admitted Patient Care Dataset
text:
Publisher
NHS Digital (now part of NHS England) receives the APCS submissions from providers delivering inpatient care to NHS patients. The raw data used for analysis is not publicly available, however, NHS Digital publishes some analyses of APC. Their Hospital Admitted Patient Care Activity, 2023-24 provides an overview of activity reported in APC.

title: Admitted Patient Care Dataset
text:
Accessing the Data
APC data is stored and accessible within several repositories across the NHS for use by approved analysts. One of the analysts will be available to discuss any potential analysis.

title: Admitted Patient Care Dataset
text:
Frequency of Publishing
Some of the data tables contain flows of daily APC updates, typically 48-72 hours in arrears. However, these are subject to change so there are still also monthly APC submission data tables. These will typically be the most appropriate source of data for our projects.

title: Outpatient Dataset
text:
Publisher
NHS Digital (now part of NHS England) receives the Outpatient submissions from providers delivering outpatient care to NHS patients. The raw data used for analysis is not publicly available, however, NHS Digital publishes some analyses of outpatient data. Their Hospital Outpatient Activity, 2023-24 provides an overview of activity reported in outpatients for 2023/24.

title: Outpatient Dataset
text:
Accessing the Data
Outpatient data is stored and accessible within several repositories across the NHS for use by approved analysts. One of the analysts will be available to discuss any potential analysis.

title: Outpatient Dataset
text:
Frequency of Publishing
Outpatients data is refreshed on a monthly basis usually with a two-month lag.

title: Operational and Performance Data Sources
text:
What topics are we interested in?
Understanding operational and performance challenges is often at the heart of any transformation project. Therefore, data sources on operational and performance issues can provide helpful context and support the development of a case for change. Topics of interest include:

Understanding the performance of A&E departments in achieving the four-hour standard. Monitoring and tracking performance against this standard over time.
Exploring elective waiting times and understanding how the backlog of elective care has changed since the pandemic.

This section provides information and links to operational and performance datasets that may be of use.

title: A&E Performance
text:
Publisher
The data is published by NHS England from submissions from each provider of Urgent and Emergency care to NHS patients.






Warning



Between May 2019 and May 2023 fourteen NHS Trusts undertook field testing of new UEC performance metrics and stopped reporting information on four hour performance. More information about the impact of CRS is available here.

title: A&E Performance
text:
Accessing the Data
The datasets can be accessed via the NHS England Statistical Work Area site. The data is published in monthly files back to 2015-16.






Warning



Prior to the end of Q1 2015/16 this data was published on a weekly basis.


If you require time-series of A&E activity data spanning considerable months speak to one of the TU analysts about how this data can be extracted from another source. This is advisable rather than trying to stitch multiple Excel or csv files together.

title: A&E Performance
text:
Frequency of Publishing
Data is published on a monthly basis typically on the 2nd Thursday of each month.

title: Cancer Waiting Times
text:
Publisher
The data is published by NHS England with each provider of cancer services to NHS patients reporting.

title: Cancer Waiting Times
text:
Accessing the Data
The datasets can be accessed from the main Cancer Waiting Times page in the NHS England statistical work area. The data is published in files containing six-months of data. Older data relating to the old standards is available in financial year extracts to 2009/10.
If you require time-series of cancer waiting times spanning considerable months speak to one of the TU analysts about how this data can be extracted from another source. This is advisable rather than trying to stitch multiple Excel or csv files together.

title: Cancer Waiting Times
text:
Frequency of Publishing
Data is published on a monthly basis typically on the 2nd Thursday of each month.

title: Referral to Treatment Waiting Times
text:
Publisher
The data is published by NHS England with each provider of NHS elective care submitting data to them.

title: Referral to Treatment Waiting Times
text:
Accessing the Data
The datasets can be accessed from the main RTT page on the NHS England statistical work area. The data is published in monthly files with separate sub-pages for each financial year. Data is available on the NHS England website back to 2011/12 with previous years available through the national archives.
If you require time-series of RTT data spanning considerable months speak to one of the TU analysts about how this data can be extracted from another source. This is advisable rather than trying to stitch multiple Excel or csv files together.

title: Referral to Treatment Waiting Times
text:
Frequency of Publishing
Data is published on a monthly basis typically on the 2nd Thursday of each month.

title: Population Health
text:
What topics are we interested in?
Understanding the health and the needs of wider populations is critical to planning the services required both now and in the future. There are a number of publicly available datasets that describe the health needs, outcomes and disparities across different populations and conditions. Topics of interest include:

Understanding differences in mortality rates across England. What are the differences across regions? How has this changed over time? Are gaps widening in specific conditions such as Cancer?
How many patients are living with a condition such as Heart Failure or Atrial Fibrillation? How does this vary across different geographic areas and compare with admission rates?
How has the prevalence of dementia changed over recent years and are we diagnosing as many cases as expected? Are people living with Dementia having their care plan reviewed in a timely manner?

title: Fingertips
text:
Publisher
Fingertips profiles are published by The Department of Health and Social Care. However, the profiles contain data from a wide variety of sources. You can find the specific publication details for each metric from the Definition option unde the Data view drop-down.

title: Fingertips
text:
Accessing the Data
The profiles can be accessed at here. Data can then be manually downloaded in a .csv format for individual indicators. There is also a Fingertips API for extracting data more efficiently in either JSON or CSV format. Of particular use is the R package - fingertipsR which can be used to access the data.

title: Fingertips
text:
Frequency of Publishing
The profiles are refreshed when new data is available so are updated on a regular basis. However, some metrics, such as mortality or outcomes, may be published with significant lags.

title: Quality Outcomes Framework (QOF)
text:
Publisher
NHS Digital (now part of NHS England) publishes QOF data following submissions by each GP Practice within England. More information on the publications can be found here.

title: Quality Outcomes Framework (QOF)
text:
Accessing the Data
The data is publicly available on the NHS Digital website under the relevant yearâ€™s publication. Data for each year can be accessed here.

title: Quality Outcomes Framework (QOF)
text:
Frequency of Publishing
QOF data is published annually, typically in September/October for the previous financial year.

title: Population Demographics Data Sources
text:
What topics are we interested in?
Population demographic data is critical for understanding the populations health systems serve. Demographic data sources can provide contextual information on topics such as:

The age and gender make-up of areas across the country.
Projections for how populations will grow and their make-up change in the future.
How does the provision of healthcare resources compare to where the populations who need these.

Therefore, any transformation project will need to understand the population that is served and what is needed in the future. This section contains descriptions and links of the various demographic data sources that will be of use.
